snippet: Testimony by Gen. Keith Alexander was the first time the Obama administration publicly admitted to developing the capacity for offensive cyberattacks.
abstract: Gen Keith Alexander, chief of military's newly-created Cyber Command, says he is establishing 13 teams of programmers and computer experts who could carry out offensive cyberattacks on foreign nations if United States were hit with major attack on its own networks; statement marks first time Obama administration has publicly admitted to developing such weapons for use in wartime.

byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI and DAVID E. SANGER

lead_paragraph: Testimony by Gen. Keith Alexander was the first time the Obama administration publicly admitted to developing the capacity for offensive cyberattacks.

headline.seo: Security Chief Says Computer Attacks Will Be Met
headline.main: Security Leader Says U.S. Would Retaliate Against Cyberattacks
headline.print_headline: Security Chief Says Cyberattacks Will Meet With Retaliation

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject
